item.title: AI and the Future of Education
item.description: The central challenge for educators in the age of AI is to prepare students to operate effectively in the face of uncertainty. The answer is not to train them for specific tasks that may soon become obsolete, but to make them as adaptable and intellectually independent as possible.

item.title: Appeasing Trump Only Invites Betrayal - as Europe’s Far Right Just Learned
item.description: With Donald Trump laying claim to Greenland, Europeans have finally realized who they are dealing with. The US president is animated less by the prospect of deal-making than by the need for domination, less by the spirit of exchange than by the perverse pleasure of belittling others and exalting himself.

item.title: Why AI Is Unlike Previous Tech Booms
item.description: The rise of AI follows a fundamentally different competitive logic than earlier technological revolutions. With massive capital requirements, high operating expenses, low switching costs, and intensifying regulatory scrutiny, success will depend less on scale and more on financial resilience and political influence.

item.title: Scott Bessent Is in Denial – and the Bond Market Is Watching
item.description: Far from warning Donald Trump against undermining foreign investors’ confidence in the US, his Treasury secretary is backing the president and downplaying the risks of a bond selloff. But markets are telling a different story.

item.title: Trump’s Imperialism Without Alibis
item.description: By asserting control over Venezuela’s primary sources of revenue, US President Donald Trump has replaced the moral rhetoric of his predecessors with a 21st-century version of colonial-era indirect rule. The result is a country that retains the symbols of self-government but functions as an American protectorate.

item.title: Philanthropy Must Dive Deeper to Save the Ocean
item.description: Despite growing pressure on marine ecosystems, ocean-health projects often remain underdeveloped because funding, policy, and implementation fail to move in sync. Philanthropy can help change that by aligning priorities, absorbing early risks, and providing the coordinating capacity that enables promising ideas to scale.

item.title: Iran’s Supreme Leader Is Trapped
item.description: Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, has built a system that survives only through repression. Yet now, a man who has never been willing to retreat confronts a dilemma from which there is no clean exit: continued internal war against his own people, or an external war that exposes his regime's fragility.

item.title: The Authoritarian Illusion
item.description: The debate and uncertainty that are intrinsic to democracies have started to look like weaknesses alongside the order and continuity promised by authoritarian regimes. But democracy is resilient and keeps returning in different forms, simultaneously obsolete and ahead of its time.

item.title: Europe Needs a New Security Framework
item.description: Recent developments have made clear that neither NATO nor the European Union is fully suited to meet the mounting challenges that Europe faces. They have also strengthened the case for reviving the old Western European Union, by institutionalizing the “coalition of the willing” that France, Germany, and the UK have already forged.

item.title: Escaping the French Budget Maze
item.description: A recent experiment involving 150 French citizens shows that when the conditions for achieving fiscal sustainability are clear and the trade-offs transparent, voters are prepared to support difficult budgetary decisions. What has been missing from the current process is not consent, but an effective method.

item.title: Can China Reverse Its Demographic Decline?
item.description: After decades of the one-child policy, the decline in China's fertility rate was inevitable, like a boulder rolling down a hill. With the problem now being compounded by numerous other factors, pushing the boulder back uphill will be exceedingly difficult, if not impossible, and will not happen quickly.

item.title: Saudi Arabia’s Stock Market Goes Global
item.description: Saudi Arabia recently opened its stock exchange, Tadawul, to all foreign investors, an important structural shift for the Gulf region. But when deciding whether to invest, foreigners will scrutinize the quality of the exchange's corporate-governance regulations, which will likely need to be fine-tuned.

item.title: Rogue America Is Changing the Global Economic Outlook
item.description: Since the year began, US President Donald Trump has ramped up his aggression in the Western Hemisphere, including military intervention in Venezuela and threats to impose large sanctions on European Union countries that oppose US annexation of Greenland. Suddenly, the international order – institutions, understandings, and alliances – that underpinned economic growth for generations are at risk.

item.title: The Big Picture
Trump’s Robber-Baron Imperialism
item.description: By normalizing territorial predation and treating foreign policy as a vehicle for personal enrichment, Donald Trump is putting America’s economy and credibility at risk. Democrats and Republicans who oppose Trump must speak up now or inherit a world where US prosperity and security have been damaged beyond repair.

item.title: Europe Needs Joint Financing and Procurement to Defend Itself
item.description: Despite rising military spending, the European Union’s defense capabilities remain constrained by fragmented procurement, uneven national budgets, and weak coordination. Bolstering resilience and reducing dependence on the United States will require mobilizing resources at the European level.

item.title: History Marches Past Davos
item.description: The World Economic Forum meeting in Davos will feature the usual pledges about stakeholder capitalism, purpose-driven business, and sustainable development. But without binding conditionalities, accountability frameworks, and risk-sharing that distinguish genuine value creators from rent extractors, it remains theater.

item.title: Is There Life After the Dollar?
item.description: Global financial stability has long depended on the dollar’s role as the main reserve currency, with the expectation that the United States would both set the rules and uphold them. As American leadership grows more erratic, that dependence has become a vulnerability, underscoring the need for a multicurrency system.

item.title: Superintelligence Is Not the Answer to Climate Change
item.description: Tech evangelists view climate change as an information problem that the arrival of AI superintelligence will solve, rather than a willpower problem that requires concrete measures, like modernizing the electrical grid and implementing a carbon tax. But there can be no miracle fix once critical planetary tipping points are crossed.

item.title: Trump Is Serving US Imperialism Raw
item.description: While previous instances of American gunboat diplomacy often paid lip service to human rights or democracy, Donald Trump has dispensed with idealistic justifications for military intervention abroad. Everyone, not least Europe, now confronts behavior that was already familiar to many across the Global South.
